abstract.text: The SDK that provides access to Openpath functionality for iOS-based mobile devices.

inlineContent.text: If viewing this documentation in XCode, be sure to choose “Swift” as the language, both in the sidebar and above.

content.text: Adding the SDK to your project

inlineContent.text: The SDK is provided as a binary framework in a CocoaPods package, delivered in a
file. The package also includes binary frameworks for all dependencies of the SDK.
To integrate the SDK:
Set up CocoaPods for your app, if it is not already. Refer to CocoaPods documentation for details.
Enable dynamic frameworks in your
Unzip the SDK archive in a known location.
Add the following to your
in the section for your app target, filling in the correct SDK directory:
If you want to use our Allegion support, add the following line as well, filling in the correct SDK directory:
Add a
hook to your Podfile as needed, as shown below and in the Example app.
Ensure your app is using Swift 5.x or later
Enable the “Build Libraries for Distribution” setting as needed (see below)
From the terminal, run
Build and run your app within Xcode
Since the SDK is distributed in binary form, the SDK’s dependencies must be built with the “Build Libraries for Distribution” build flag set to
Yes
. This tells Xcode to build those dependencies in such a way that the SDK can call into them without needing to be recompiled.
For a simple app, this can be accomplished with the following steps:
In Xcode, select the build settings for your app target, and chose
Yes
for “Build Libraries for Distribution”
From the terminal run (or re-run)
Cocoapods will apply that build setting to all Pod projects, including
and all its dependencies.

In a more complex app, you may not want to apply that setting to all Pod projects. For example, this can cause problems with some React Native libraries. In that case, here’s some code you can add to your
that will apply the setting only to OpenpathMobile’s dependencies:
Add this somewhere near the top of the Podfile:

code: top_dependencies = installer.pod_targets.find { |pt| pt.name == root }&.dependencies or return []
puts "Target #{target} is an Openpath dependency, so setting BUILD_LIBRARY_FOR_DISTRIBUTION"
# Some depended-on Pods set this to an obsolete iOS version
# None of the Openpath dependencies need to be signed

inlineContent.text: Add a post_install block to the Podfile, or add to your existing one:

code: # Any other post_install scripts go here

inlineContent.text: Re-run
Reload the app in Xcode and rebuild
We use explicit versions in the

files for all third-party Cocoapod dependencies. Theoretically it should be possible to increase the patch-version for any of these dependencies, following standard semantic versioning rules. In reality, not all libraries follow semantic versioning perfectly, so we can’t guarantee the SDK will work correctly with all future versions of dependencies. (Feel free to try. The typical failure is an instant crash at runtime, so it’s easy to test, at least.)

content.text: An alternative way to incorporate dependencies (for troubleshooting only)

inlineContent.text: In the past, new Xcode releases or Swift language changes have caused the SDK to be unable to find its third-party dependencies, resulting in runtime crashes at startup with an error message like “symbol not found”.
If you encounter this, you may have better luck specifying binary dependencies, which you can do by modifying the
files. We include
files with pre-built binaries for each dependency. These are not used by default but are available for troubleshooting. To use them, modify the SDK’s
files by removing the
lines and adding the frameworks to
. For example:
would change to:
NOTE: We do not distribute an
for OpenSSL, as that is already published in binary form on Cocoapods.

content.text: Enabling background modes and privacy keys

inlineContent.text: The Openpath SDK requires the ability to access Bluetooth and location while the app is in the background. (The user will be prompted to approve these permissions interactively on first use.)
Ensure your app’s
file contains the following
background modes
Openpath requires that the user has the following settings on their phone:
(Global) Bluetooth -> ON
(Global) Location Services -> ON
(optional) (Global) Fitness Tracking -> ON
Openpath Bluetooth Permission -> Enabled
Openpath Location Permission
ALWAYS - for Wave/Touch to unlock reliably
WHEN IN USE - for unlocks only when the app is opened
(optional) Openpath Motion & Fitness Permission -> Enabled
Bluetooth
and
Location Services

are used to communicate with Openpath readers, to ensure that the app properly wakes up when near readers, and to allow the Wave feature to work reliably. Openpath never tracks or stores a user’s location information for any other purpose.
Motion & Fitness
is used to help save battery and reduce data usage, as Openpath will turn off unnecessary activity if the phone is stationary.
Include the following
privacy keys
in your

so that when a user is prompted for permission, the given text is displayed. The strings below are examples, and you may re-word them as you wish. Note that the SDK has intercom support compiled in but it is not enabled, so while the key is required in Info.plist it will never be displayed to the user and the SDK will never access the microphone.

code: <string>We need access to Bluetooth to discover and unlock nearby entries.</string>
<string>We need access to Bluetooth to discover and unlock nearby entries.</string>
We need "Always" location permission in order to discover nearby entries when the app is
closed. This allows you to unlock via "Touch" without opening your phone. We do not store,
log, or share your location data.
We need "Always" location permission in order to discover nearby entries when the app is
closed. This allows you to unlock via "Touch" without opening your phone. We do not store,
log, or share your location data.
We need "While Using App" location permission in order to discover nearby entries. We do not
store, log, or share your location data.
We use motion to turn off services when your phone is stationary in order to save battery
We use the microphone to connect to intercoms, if applicable.

inlineContent.text: For iOS14, Apple added the ability for location accuracy to be reduced or approximated. In order for unlocks to be verified as “on-site” and near a reader according to geofence rules, the SDK needs full location accuracy, so this setting must be off. The following can be added to your
file, though the default value is
if this key is not included.
The Openpath SDK uses
beacon region monitoring
so the SDK can wake up and start services when the device comes within range of readers.
Apple allows for a maximum of 20 beacons regions to be monitored per app. Openpath monitors 11 regions, so there are 9 remaining regions available for your use.
In order to help prevent region identifier collision, Openpath regions are prefixed with
Once you’ve added the framework to your project, updated
, and installed the CocoaPods libraries, you are ready to write some code.
The
class is a singleton, available through the
static variable.
Set your class as the SDK’s delegate:
IMPORTANT: Always access
on the main thread.
The iOS example app uses the Openpath Mobile Access Core SDK to:
Provision one or more user mobile credentials onto the app
Switch between users on the app
View the list of entries that the user has access to
Unlock an entry
Unprovision all the users or select one to unprovision from the list of inactive users
The Example App targets iOS 15+ and uses advanced features that may not be available in previous iOS versions.
For the purposes of this demo, we will show provisioning through two different ways.

The app can be provisioned via email and password by allowing a user to log in and generate their own mobile setup token to use for provisioning. Usually, only a user with admin rights to the Openpath Control Center (admin portal) has a password.

The app can be provisioned via mobile setup token. In practice, most users won’t have an Openpath password. We recommend that you create a service user (super admin) in the Openpath Control Center, and use that service user in your cloud to make Openpath API calls to generate a temporary mobile setup token for a particular user’s mobile credential. Then this token should be passed from your cloud server to the mobile app and into the “provision” SDK function.
For more information on the provisioning workflow, please refer to the Openpath Mobile Access SDK README section entitled “Provisioning Workflow”.

A JWE consisting of five parameters as specified in
The JWE is fully initialized with those five (immutable) parameters.
All representations of the JWE or it’s parts like it’s compact serialization or the plaintext can be derived from those five parameters.
Therefore (and to keep immutability) it does not cache such representations.
As discussed, it is the responsibility of the framework user to cache e.g. the plaintext. Of course this will have to be communicated clearly.
